text: A lot of people think that the only time you really need to present well is when you have a big stage talk and you make the big investment in the script. The big investment in the contrasting story. I'll tell you a dirty little secret. I can get my husband to do chores for me on the weekends with a real quick, what is, what could be new bliss. So, the ability to just have that contrast as a framework in your brain during a meeting, on a phone call, any moment of influence, like literally it works. It works in any format.
speaker: Nancy Duarte
context: Lenny asks about when to apply Nancy's story structure methodology to presentations. Nancy explains her 'what is, what could be, new bliss' framework - a simplified version of her three-act story structure where you present the current state, contrast it with an ideal future state, and paint a picture of the benefits. She reveals that this technique works not just for major presentations but for any moment of influence, even convincing her husband to help with household tasks.
text_ko: 많은 사람들이 진짜로 발표를 잘해야 하는 때는 큰 무대에서 발표할 때 뿐이고, 그때 스크립트(script)에 크게 투자하고 대비되는 이야기(contrasting story)에 공을 들여야 한다고 생각해요. 그런데 제가 하나 비밀을 알려드릴게요. 주말에 남편에게 집안일을 시킬 때도 '지금(what is)은 이렇고, 이렇게 바뀌면 어떨까(what could be)' 같은 아주 짧은 대비만 보여줘도 바로 움직여요. 회의 중이든 전화 통화든, 영향력을 미치는 순간(moment of influence)에 머릿속에 그 대비를 프레임워크(framework)처럼 갖고 있는 능력만 있어도 진짜 효과가 있어요. 어떤 형식(format)에서든 통해요.
text_zh: 很多人觉得只有在大型演讲台上，花大力气准备演讲稿、精心设计对比故事的时候，才需要好好展示。我跟你们说个小秘密吧。我在家里用一个超简单的"现状对比理想状态"的套路，就能让我老公周末帮我干家务。所以说，在开会时、打电话时、任何需要影响别人的时候，脑子里有这种对比的思维框架，真的特别管用。不管什么场合都好使。
text_es: Mucha gente piensa que solo necesitas presentar bien cuando tienes una charla importante en un escenario grande y haces una gran inversión en el guión. La gran inversión en la historia de contraste. Te voy a contar un secretito. Puedo conseguir que mi marido haga las tareas domésticas los fines de semana con un rápido "qué es lo que hay ahora" versus "qué podría ser la nueva felicidad". O sea, tener esa capacidad de contraste como marco mental durante una reunión, en una llamada, en cualquier momento de influencia - literalmente funciona. Funciona en cualquier formato.
key_sentence: Contrast as a framework works in any moment of influence.

text: Empathy is important to Duarte, everything we do is empathy first. And some of it comes from my own childhood story a little bit. I was raised by a clinically narcissistic mom and narcissist are missing the empathy gene. So, I feel like that void of not having it modeled for me is why I keep clawing at empathy as being important.
speaker: Nancy Duarte
context: Lenny asks Nancy why empathy is so central to her presentation methodology and what it looks like in practice. Nancy explains that empathy is the foundation of all her work at Duarte, stemming from her personal experience growing up without empathy being modeled for her. She believes this childhood experience drives her focus on making empathy the core of effective communication, especially since many people work for bosses who lack empathy.
vocabulary_highlights: void of not having it modeled
text_ko: 공감(empathy)은 Duarte에게 정말 중요해요. 우리가 하는 모든 일은 공감부터 시작해요. 그리고 이건 제 어린 시절 이야기에서 조금 비롯된 면도 있어요. 저는 임상적으로 나르시시즘(narcissism)이 있던 엄마 밑에서 자랐어요. 나르시시스트(narcissist)들은 공감(empathy)이 결여돼 있는 경우가 많아요. 그래서 제게 공감을 보여주는 본보기가 없었던 그 공허함 때문에, 제가 공감(empathy)을 그렇게 중요하게 여기고 계속 붙잡으려고 애쓰는 것 같아요.
text_zh: 同理心对Duarte来说特别重要，我们做任何事都把同理心放在第一位。这跟我小时候的经历也有点关系。我妈妈是临床诊断的自恋型人格(narcissistic personality)，自恋的人天生就缺乏同理心基因。正因为从小没有人给我做这方面的榜样，所以我现在才会一直强调同理心的重要性，一直在这方面努力。
text_es: Para Duarte, la empatía es fundamental, todo lo que hacemos parte de la empatía primero. Y parte de esto viene un poco de mi propia historia de la infancia. Me crié con una mamá clínicamente narcisista y los narcisistas no tienen el gen de la empatía. Entonces, siento que ese vacío de no haber tenido ese ejemplo es por lo que sigo insistiendo tanto en que la empatía es importante.
key_sentence: Clawing at empathy fills the void of not having it modeled.

text: When I got to really digging into the mentor, I realized it's really the mentor in myths and movies that's the presenter and who really holds the power in the room of a presentation is the audience, the audience gets to make a choice if they accept or reject your idea. So, the balance of power is with them and not you. So, it really is the role of the presenter to be the mentor.
speaker: Nancy Duarte
context: Nancy is explaining her core philosophy that 'the audience is the hero' of any presentation. She describes how she initially thought the presenter was the hero since they're the central figure on stage, but through studying storytelling archetypes, she realized the presenter should actually play the role of the mentor. The audience holds the real power because they get to choose whether to accept or reject the presenter's ideas, similar to how mentors in myths and movies guide heroes on their journeys.
text_ko: 멘토(mentor)에 대해 깊이 파고들어 보니, 신화나 영화에 나오는 멘토가 발표자(presenter)로 여겨지곤 하지만, 실제 발표에서는 진짜 힘을 쥐고 있는 쪽은 청중(audience)더라고요. 청중은 당신의 아이디어를 받아들일지 거부할지 선택할 권한이 있으니까요. 그래서 힘의 균형(balance of power)은 청중 쪽에 있고 발표자 쪽에 있는 게 아니에요. 결국 발표자(presenter)의 역할은 멘토(mentor)가 되는 거예요.
text_zh: 当我深入研究导师这个概念时，我意识到其实在神话故事和电影里，导师才是那个做演示的人。而在演示现场真正掌握主动权的是听众，听众有选择权，他们可以接受你的想法，也可以拒绝。所以主导权其实在他们手里，不在你这儿。因此，演示者真正应该扮演的角色就是导师。
text_es: Cuando me puse a analizar bien el tema del mentor, me di cuenta de que en realidad el mentor de los mitos y las películas es el presentador, y quien realmente tiene el poder en una presentación es la audiencia - ellos son los que deciden si aceptan o rechazan tu idea. O sea, el equilibrio del poder está con ellos, no contigo. Entonces, el rol del presentador es ser el mentor.
key_sentence: The balance of power lies with the audience, not the presenter.

text: So, that rise and fall of hey, here's our current problem, here's a solution, or here's the state of the union. But we imagine it could look like this. There's so many different ways to build that cadence of contrast that's so lovely. I mean it really works. I think the talk came out in 2011 and the amounts of notes and emails of things people have accomplished by changing the structure of their presentation has been really astounding.
speaker: Nancy Duarte
context: Nancy is describing her famous presentation structure that creates a visual pattern like 'pumpkin teeth' - alternating between 'what is' (current reality) and 'what could be' (future possibility). She explains how this cadence of contrast works by building tension and releasing it, similar to how stories naturally flow. Nancy mentions that since sharing this methodology in her 2011 TEDx talk, she has received countless messages from people who achieved remarkable results by restructuring their presentations using this approach.
text_ko: 그러니까 '지금 우리 문제는 이거고, 해결책은 이거다' 혹은 '현황보고(state of the union)' 식으로 오르내리는 흐름이 있는데, 우리는 이걸 이렇게 보일 수도 있다고 상상해요. 대조의 리듬(cadence of contrast)을 만드는 방법이 정말 다양해요. 정말 멋지고, 효과가 있어요. 그 강연(talk)이 2011년에 나왔는데, 발표 구조를 바꿔서 사람들이 해낸 일들에 대해 받은 메모랑 이메일의 양이 정말 어마어마해요.
text_zh: 所以就是这种起起伏伏的节奏感，比如"嘿，这是我们现在面临的问题，这是解决方案"，或者"这是现状，但我们设想可以是这个样子"。你可以用很多不同的方式来打造这种对比的节奏感，真的特别棒。我是说，这招真的很管用。我记得那个演讲是2011年出来的，从那以后收到的各种留言和邮件，讲他们通过改变演示结构取得的成果，真的让人刮目相看。
text_es: Entonces, esa subida y bajada de "oye, este es nuestro problema actual, aquí tienes una solución", o "este es el estado de las cosas, pero imagínate que pudiera verse así". Hay muchísimas formas diferentes de crear ese ritmo de contrastes que funciona de maravilla. En serio, funciona increíble. Creo que la charla salió en 2011 y la cantidad de notas y emails de cosas que la gente ha logrado simplemente cambiando la estructura de sus presentaciones ha sido impresionante.
key_sentence: The cadence of contrast creates a lovely rise and fall in presentations.

text: We made a mental model he could hold up in his head and the structure was so simple and clear. And then there was three moments where we're like just, I don't know, just grab a piece of paper or go to a whiteboard and just start to draw in front of him. Let him see your eyes, let him have eye contact. Let him see your passion. Don't be dispassionately looking at this computer.
speaker: Nancy Duarte
context: Nancy is telling the story of helping an executive from a multinational company who needed to petition his CEO for a $100 million budget. Instead of creating traditional slides, Nancy's team developed a simple mental framework the executive could remember, combined with moments where he would draw key concepts on paper or whiteboards during the meeting. This approach allowed for direct eye contact and emotional connection rather than both people staring at a computer screen during such a high-stakes conversation.
text_ko: 우리는 그가 머릿속에 쉽게 떠올릴 수 있는 멘탈 모델(mental model)을 만들었고, 구조가 아주 단순하고 명확했어요. 그리고 세 번 정도는 '그냥 종이 한 장 집어 들거나 화이트보드로 가서 앞에서 바로 그려 보여줘'라고 우리가 속으로 생각하던 순간들이 있었어요. 눈을 마주치게 하고 눈 맞춤을 유지하세요. 당신의 열정을 보여 주세요. 열정 없이 컴퓨터만 무심하게 바라보지 마세요.
text_zh: 我们给他建了一个思维模型(mental model)，让他脑子里能有个清晰的框架，结构特别简单明了。然后有三个关键时刻，我们就是，怎么说呢，随手拿张纸或者走到白板前，直接在他面前画出来。让他能看到你的眼神，跟他有眼神交流。让他感受到你的热情。别老盯着电脑屏幕，那样太冷冰冰的。
text_es: Creamos un modelo mental que él pudiera visualizar claramente en su cabeza y la estructura era súper simple y clara. Y luego hubo tres momentos donde dijimos, no sé, simplemente agarra una hoja de papel o ve al pizarrón y empieza a dibujar frente a él. Que vea tus ojos, que haya contacto visual. Que vea tu pasión. No te quedes ahí viendo la computadora sin mostrar emoción.
key_sentence: A mental model helps him hold up clear structure and see your passion.

text: What happens is they commit to your idea, they commit to your program, your project, and they're like enthused at first. And then they go into the state of, oh my God, this is harder than I thought. It's a long slog. This climb is getting exhausted. I don't know if I have this much fight in me to make this all work, not fight with each other, but like, oh my God, I'm having to overcome this roadblock and that roadblock.
speaker: Nancy Duarte
context: Nancy is explaining the 'fight and climb' phase from her book 'Illuminate,' which describes how to lead people through major organizational changes. She's describing the predictable pattern that occurs after people initially commit to a new initiative - they start enthusiastic but then encounter the difficult middle phase where the work becomes harder than expected. Nancy explains this isn't about interpersonal conflict, but rather the struggle of overcoming obstacles and maintaining momentum during challenging transformational work.
text_ko: 처음엔 아이디어나 프로그램, 프로젝트에 헌신하고 신나해요. 그런데 곧 '세상에, 생각보다 훨씬 어렵네'라는 상태가 돼요. 긴 고행 같고, 오르는 게 점점 지치게 만들어요. '이걸 다 해낼 만큼 내 안에 싸울 힘이 있을까' 하고 의심하게 되죠. 여기서 서로 싸우자는 얘기가 아니라, '세상에, 이 장애물 저 장애물을 계속 넘어야 하네' 하는 그런 심정이에요.
text_zh: 情况是这样的，他们一开始对你的想法、你的方案、你的项目特别有信心，也很有热情。但是后来就变成了，天哪，这比我想象的要难多了。这是个漫长的硬仗啊。爬这座山都快累死了。我不知道自己还有没有这么大的精力把这事儿搞定，不是说跟别人斗，而是天哪，这个坎儿得过，那个坎儿也得过。
text_es: Lo que pasa es que se comprometen con tu idea, se comprometen con tu programa, tu proyecto, y al principio están súper motivados. Pero después entran en esa fase de "ay, Dios mío, esto está mucho más difícil de lo que pensé." Es como una caminata larguísima. Esta subida los tiene agotados. No saben si tienen la energía suficiente para hacer que todo esto funcione - no me refiero a pelearse entre ellos, sino más bien ese "ay, no manches, tengo que superar este obstáculo y después ese otro obstáculo."
key_sentence: The long slog makes them question if they have this much fight in me.
